Orlando da Costa Ferreira Junior

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/4282395749173635
  • Última atualização do currículo em 21/11/2018

Possui graduação em Medicina pela Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (1980) e doutorado em Ciências Biológicas (Biofísica) pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (1987). Atualmente é professor da Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro. Tem experiência na área de Imunologia, com ênfase em Imunologia Celular, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: fibronectina, hiv, htlv, doador de sangue e doença de chagas. (Texto informado pelo autor)

2008 - 2009
Determination of the Incidence Rate of Dengue Virus Infection among Repeat Blood Donors.
Descrição: For many years it was believed that dengue transmission required the simultaneous presence a susceptible humans, a competent mosquito vector, and dengue virus. No person-to-person transmission was thought to occur. In the last two decades at least four cases of dengue transmission through a needlestick injury (1, 2, 4, 5) were reported in the literature. All cases described implicated viremic patient experiencing dengue symptoms when their blood contaminated the health care worker. Although blood was involved these examples do not have a direct translation into the blood transfusion arena. In the 2001 one case of dengue transmission through bone marrow transplantation (3) and in 2002 one case transmitted by red blood cell transfusion (6,7) were reported in Puerto Rico and Hong Kong, respectively. In both cases, donors (BM and RBC) made their donation during the viremic period but 1 to 2 days before the onset of symptoms. Later they develop classical dengue disease which is the most frequent form of dengue illness during outbreaks in the Americas. Although this two cases proof the concept that dengue can be transmitted by blood transfusion, its magnitude is far from being understood. For instance, we do not have a precise information on the percentage of individuals who is assymptomatic during a given epidemic. Literature reports provide estimates from 30% to 70% of asymptomatic individual at an epidemic. This wide variation is ususally explained by different factors such as serotype virulence, herd immunity and population genetic background where the epidemics is taking place. Also largelly unknown is the level and lenght of viremic period among assymptomatic individuals. It is obvious that a short and low level viremia will have a moderate impact on the risk of dengue transmission by transfusion. Finally, it is possible that many cases of of transfusion-transmitted dengue is occurring in Rio de Janeiro every summer (between November and March) where den.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Orlando da Costa Ferreira Junior - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): The Foundation of the International Society of Blood Transfusion - Auxílio financeiro.
